author: mgr1994

title: IO FPV: A 3D PRINTED HEXACOPTER FOR FPV

description.text:
This is a hexacopter design for fast FPV flying.
It has motors tilted forward, so it can fly faster with better air flow.
It is based on designs by Brendan22 on thingiverse (http://www.thingiverse.com/Brendan22) and our own.
It is 3d printable and does not need bolts, it just need zip ties.
All the information for the multicopter set up is on the video at the end.
Video with better quality in vimeo:
https://vimeo.com/115294510 http://youtu.be/LyMtKITcNm4 History:
14/4/15
New video: https://youtu.be/mJ5Dg3-OLNw
28/12/2014
Added new top cover design for mobius action cam, give better support of the magnets.
Added a cover for go pro 3, not tested...

I have an ultimaker 2, so thats the printer was used for the project by me so far.  infill was at 100% in all parts.  
I printed the arms at layer height 0.1mm and speed at 50mm/s, infill 100% , it is slow but arms which are base on brendan22 arms are really strong on PLA.  
Body was at layer height 0.2 and 70 mm/s, If use colorfab XT I disable combing.  
Top cover was printed with and without support, it ended much better with support grid with overhang angle for support at 87 deg.  
Arms needed to fit inside the body with a rubber hammer (press fit) and cover fitted better if it was printed at 105% scale  
Magnets used are 8mm diameter and 1mm height, ebay have several places to buy cheap magnets...

title: Customizable Tower of 3D Skill Badges
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Now you can print a 'Tower' of 3D Skill Badges, to really give your printer a workout.

Select the number of badges you want to print (1 to 10), and add your own custom text for the sides. The polygon_count is for rounding off the corners more/less. Be careful, this thing has lots of gaps to test the ability of your printer to 'bridge' across them, and at least on my ToM, I need to keep a close eye on the build when this is going on. I use a piece of an aluminum yardstick to help make sure that no bits of the filament stick up above the build surface. I have also found it helpful sometimes to apply some tape ( blue painters tape ) to the bottom of the build, but it can be tricky doing this, while the build is in process! You can now adjust the height of the stacking pylons, as well as adjusting the overall height.
My first two attempts haven't quite successfully made it all the way to the end of the print, I'll keep trying though! I hope you do too!

title: Extruder Block Top Plate Enhanced Upgrade for Dual Extrusion

description.text: This design (based on user toreg's original design) enables consistent filament feeding by creating enough room for both extruders to use the "Minimalistic MK8 Upgrade" by user emmett in tandem with my "Spring Enhancer / Spring Compressor". The original plate that ships with the Replicator Dual is a little too wide, which obstructs the range of motion of the Minimalistic MK8 Upgrade arms. I simply added tube holders to toreg's original design. Then, I plucked out the little grey cylinder things from the original plate that came with the replicator, and inserted them into this new "Replicator Extruder Block Top Plate Enhanced." I like those grey things because they allow the filament tubes to swivel as the extruder block moves around during printing. NOTE: I recommend you also print this cable/wire manager pole to relieve tension from all the wires going to your extruder block: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:607733 DUAL EXTRUSION SUCCESS: I used the "cone" and "pendant" examples from MakerBot Desktop to test dual extrusion. It worked!! The pendant came out perfectly. You'll notice the cone is a little messy, and that's because I purposely put it sideways on the build plate (a non-optimal orientation) to test color-matching rafts and supports. The picture with the cone on the build plate looks extra messy, but in fact it turned out pretty decently as you can see from the final result.

Print as-is with no rafts or supports. The STL is purposely upside down because otherwise there would be an overhang. After printing, pluck out the grey cylinder things that sit inside the filament tube holes from the original extruder top plate that came with your Replicator, and insert those into this new replacement piece. FYI, print settings I used:
MakerBot Desktop PLA LOW Resolution settings:
0.3mm Layer Height
10% Infill NOTE: It may seem odd to you that the tube holder for the left and right extruders are not the same distance apart from the center. However, this was on purpose. I measured where the tube holders would best align with the Minimalistic MK8 Upgrade's tube holes. I'm not sure if this varies from Replicator to Replicator. For me, I found that: The left extruder's filament hole is about 1.65cm to the left of the center screws. The right extruder's filament hole is about 1.4cm to the right of the center screws. UPDATE: My right extruder still had a random jam, so I added this filament duster and added a few drops of safflower oil onto the spongy material.

author: velzey

title: Rudog dual extruder or single
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Rudog, vigilantly guarding the presents from no-good-doers like Krampus, and keeping an eye on the sky. Rudog is an adorable little buddy, print out your new best friend to keep an eye on the sky  for Santa so the kids can go to bed! Rudog will make sure Dad doesn't eat Santa's snacks too!   
Rudog makes a great Christmas decoration and a wonderful tree ornament.   
Unlike the real version, Rudog won't thrash around in chaos trying to rid himself of antlers, and you don't have to worry about Rudog knocking the tree over, or jumping on and barking at the relatives.

To get your Rudog to look like the one in the picture, you'll need a couple of things.  
The first is a dual extruder printer, and the second is a precisely timed color change or a precisely fused piece of filament for the main body of the print.  
Similar effects can be gained  by doing 1 color change for the nose and antlers and then painting the nose red.  
For dual extruders, print the dog part of the file with support, and the antlers and eyes portion without. We used RepG.  
For single extruders, exterior support should work fine.

description.text: The 3D print in the picture was done with my FlashForge Finder, a wonderful machine I got from Gearbest.com (affiliate link: https://www.gearbest.com/3d-printers-3d-printer-kits/pp_693032.html?lkid=11324000). The slicer (FlashPrint) can also generate organic support beams next to normal support for easier removal. I lightly sprayed it with copper paint. I used MeshMixer to make this 123D Catch scan 3D printable. I deleted all the surroundings that were also scanned (table etc.), made a plane cut of the solid to create a flat base and oriented it upright. I touched up the model a bit with the ShrinkSmooth brush and scaled the model up to 125 mm in height. Try MeshMixer and download it here: http://www.meshmixer.com The original files can be found here: http://www.123dapp.com/catch/Gargoyle/3219951 http://www.3dwp.nl

description.text: Based on user GeraldO's original design. I couldn't get all my wires to fit in the very snug Strain Relief upgrade, so I modified it to have a pole instead. The cable tie I'm using is some kind of velcro thing that my mom bought because she hates seeing wires around the house. Here's the link to it.

Print as-is. I used MakerWare PLA STANDARD Resolution settings, but my pole came out a little squiggly. You may want to try HIGH resolution. Standard Resolution:
.20mm Layer Height
100% Infill UPDATE: I created "v2", which has a rectangular shaped pole that should print more reliably, and therefore be sturdier. I recommend printing with 100% infill.

author: FLAIO

description.text: Marble elevator (hence Marblevator) combined with snap together sectional track and adjustable tressels made using Sketchup 8, ReplicatorG and a Replicator 2 3D printer. Video of Marbelvator in action at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MqLSIlFAPhw. Video of Marbelvator track with cross unders at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0wOupVt8v1c. Video of a Marblevator track using only 5 track sections at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QmMVvP7tny4. Video of Marblevator using 14mm marbles at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7KzasInFa6g. Video of prototype at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pmjuzHZ6XwY. With the Marbelvator, sectional track and adjustable tressels, an enumerable number of track layouts can be assembled with snap / slide together construction. Print more track sections and tressels and build a bigger Marblevator.

For years I always wanted to know what was inside a can of spray paint that rattled when shook. After emptying a can of spray paint, I donned a face shield, protective gloves, and paint spray suitable clothing (as should you if you decide to use what's inside), and grabbed a hammer and chisel and broke open the can. Now finally I know; a 10mm metal ball. What to do with that metal ball? Well of course, buy a Replicator2, download free Sketchup 8 and ReplicatorG software, and repurpose that ball by making a Marblevator (Metalballevator didn't sound right). So update your outdoor furniture with a new coat of spray paint (I know, you were thinking of graffiti), don your protective gear, free that 10mm metal ball from a life in the landfill, and build your own Marblevator. The Marblevator requires the aforementioned metal spray paint ball (Or balls. Actually, I've heard 10mm marbles and beads are much more safely attainable, but I have not verified as such), a Replicator2, ReplicatorG software (free), PLA, 2 wires, a dc motor and a dc power supply. And if you don't like my track segments, you'll need Sketchup 8 (free) to modify the included ".skp" files to make your own. Unless noted otherwise, the following ReplicatorG settings are used (using the GCode/Generate dialog): Infill: 100%
Layer Height: .15mm
Shells : 1
Feedrate: 80
Travel Feedrate: 150
Print temperature: 230 The various components were designed to print as fast as I could design them to print with minimal plastic (well, at least on a Replicator 2 using ReplicatorG with the recommended settings). Any further suggestions are welcomed. Make sure your printer is tuned for .15mm printing. 1) Buy this motor: 6VDC 45 RPM Pinky Finger Sized Gear Motor 1" Long x 15/32" x 3/8"
from either amazon.com or directly from http://sciplus.com/p/MICROMOTOR_47952. In this application, the motor requires 10 to 20 ma to run which is suitable for a small power supply, battery and/or solar panel use. 2) Buy a power source. I've used a "wall wart" variable power supply (3, 4.5, 6 vdc, the motor is rated to 6 vdc) and run mine at 3 or 4.5 vdc depending on the track design. I've also used a bench top linear variable power supply which comes in handy for track testing, but is not necessary. And I've also used 2 AA batteries, as well as a solar cell in bright sunlight (4.5 volt, 1.5 watt). 3) Print tressels. Print 10 each of each tressel piece (arm, base and clip). You'll want more. Base should be printed at 20% infill to avoid warpage and save PLA. After printing, snap off the round skirt at the bottom of each tressel clip, and if required, carefully separate the jaws of the tressel clip using a modeling knife. The tressel clip should now act like a "clothes pin". Pinch the handles, insert the tressel arm to the desired length, then let go of the handles. The base slides on the opposite end of the clip. It is a tight fit. 3) Print track segments. Each track segment has a female and male end. The female end also serves as the tressel attachment point. On the bottom of the female end is a small square hole which will be hidden when the tressel arm is attached. When you need to disassemble a track, remove the tressel arm, insert a small jewelers screw driver (or similar small object) into this hole, and press upward to separate the track segments. Following this procedure avoids having to pull the track segments apart and possibly separating (e.g. breaking, which of course can be fixed with cyanoacrylate glue if required, as if I've ever broken a track in haste, sigh) the track from the male track segment. 4) Print track start and track end. These components connect the track to the Marblevator. Track Start snaps onto step number 5 (the highest step) of the Marblevator. It has a male track connector extending down. Track End snaps onto one of the remaining 4 steps. It has a female track connector extending down. For short tracks, Track End is snapped onto step 4 (first step below the step 5). For large tracks, Track End is snapped onto step 1 (bottom step). Which step is used depends on how long the track is. If the track is designed too steep, you'll lose your marbles (sorry, had to use that) in that they will jump the track. If the track is designed too shallow, your marbles stop. 5) Print arm. 6) Print staircase. This is a long print, but has been reliable for me as designed; keep your fingers crossed. 7) Print stair steps. Print at 20% infill to prevent warpage, save PLA and minimize the weight that the motor must lift. 8) Assemble the Marblevator (staircase, stair steps, motor and arm). Begin by soldering red and black wires to the motor and - terminals. Slide motor into motor holder on staircase until the motor shaft just slightly enters into the inside of staircase (use the access hole on the opposite side of the motor holder to view motor shaft position). Orient stair steps such that the long narrow slot is vertical, then slide into staircase such that the slot surrounds the stair step guides inside staircase. Once installed, stair steps should move vertically with ease such that when you lift stair steps up then release, stair steps will easily fall to the bottom of staircase. Next, press motor further into the motor mount such that the shaft is half way through staircase. Press arm onto motor shaft via the access hole such that the motor shaft flat and arm flat mate, and the arm is inside the large rectangular hole in stair steps. Finally press motor all the way into the motor holder while positioning the arm on the shaft to allow it to be centered in staircase. 9) Assemble tressels (see picture). 10) Assemble and adjust track. This is your "free form" design. The prototype video shows an oblong track, the final design video shows a slightly more complex track. However, loop backs, circles, etc. are possible. When your track is complete, carefully adjust the tressel heights for a smooth descent from track start to track end. "Tuning" your track is crucial. For example, you may start with a rapid descent and end by slowing the descent via increasing the tressel height at the end of your track before returning to the Marblevator. Gravity is relatively constant (for the time being), so experiment with tressel heights to obtain the best combination between track slope and track length. The tracks I've assembled run for days without a marble jumping the track. 11) Connect motor to power supply. This is also your "free form" design. The video shows mine connected to a variable dc bench power supply with alligator clips. Your choice. 12) Marblevate. Make new tracks. Show off your track building skills and please post your tracks! 13) Questions? Send a comment, I'll try my best to respond. Have fun. Makes a great gift for your aspiring engineer.

comments.text:
I did notice that (the tressel arms). Have not given it any thought as to why that would be.
I tried to use all the height of the staircase and essentially minimized the track length while avoiding derailment. (A longer track either requires more underpasses or more desktop space.)
I did have to cut down the tressel clips and arms for the lowest part of the track.
comments.author: FollowMeOn

comments.text:
First, I want to say this is very amazing to print!! One area that just failed on me is the arm that attaches to the motor shaft, but not in the way you think! I've probably only used it maybe 10 min total and the tip of the arm (which I printed in ABS while the rest of the machine is PLA) simply wore out. It is very minimal but enough that the stroke was not high enough to move the marble up to the next rung. I am going to make a derivative in scad format to make it an eccentric cam rather than just an "arm" and max out the diameter to fit into the "slot" in the stair steps. This will make the hole stronger for motor attachment, give slightly more stroke, and make the motion smoother.
I also noticed motor direction may matter. It tended to be more reliable in the reverse direction from the red dot on the motor for wiring. YMMV
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: Just noticed the picture of your track.  Great work!
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: Thanks!  Make sure the arm fits freely on the vertical axis of the large rectangle in stair steps.  If it doesn't (and gets hung), the torque of the motor will ruin the hole.  I had to sand some of the edges at times where the PLA oozed a bit for a good fit.  Thanks for building it and glad you like it!
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: Like I said, that's not the failure. The problem is, the arm is just barely enough when new to lift the steps high enough for the ball to move to the next level and mine wore down just enough that the marble would not rock to the next step. It's amazingly close but that's how touchy the design is. Another 0.5mm length on the arm would prevent this.
comments.author: FollowMeOn

comments.text: Hmmm, guess I don't understand. The design lifts the stair steps 3mm clear of the staircase. Moving the large rectangle down on stair step will provide even more clearance, however stair step will not go as low and may not pick up a marble from the lower step (moving the motor mount up gives the same effect, but staircase takes much longer to print than stair step). Glad you found a fix for the difficulties you were experiencing.
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: It's barely even in the version that I printed (the day you uploaded it). It took a fair amount of filing to get the staircase down to where the balls rolled properly onto the new step. I'm not sure how it could be 3mm clearance for you, and perhaps 0.5 short for me. Did you revise the geometry?
comments.author: FollowMeOn

comments.text: I just measured the prototype (which has been running non-stop for about 5 weeks now) and the step clears the case by 2.5 mm, and drops below the case by 1 mm.  I do not believe any revisions were made to the step, case or arm files.  I'll let you know if I find something.
comments.author: laird

comments.text: Weird. In my print (which printed fine) the step drops well below the case and doesn't quite clear it. I did print in ABS rather than PLA, so it's possible that ABS shrinking (2%) might be a factor, in that perhaps the vertically printed case and the horizontally printed step shrank slightly differently, but I don't see how it could make a 3mm difference in the position of the bottom step.

comments.text: 2% over the height of steps could cause an approximate 2 mm difference in total height.  One solution is to move the steps large rectangle down by how short steps are of case.

title: 3D printer cooling fan  - Intake Velocity Stack!

description.text:
Ok, so you are a 3D printer person, but also a car nut. How to "hot rod" that printer? Why, add a velocity stack to the cooling fan of course! This has no real need, but should increase fan flow by 5%ish. I made just because it looks cool :) Shown here on my Printrbot, but should work with any same sized fan with a clear path to it.  
I included a second version with a full radius bell and a center flow deflector to keep the air moving over only the fan blades. This one will also print with no supports "Bell up" if you get all your settings right. I had a few stringers on the backside, but still happy with the print. I print with 10% fill at 15mm/sec in PLA

Its a bit tricky to print. I printed "bell down". Left a few fuzzies at the screw mounts, but just filed the fluff off. Printing Bell up, needs lots of supports, with not as nice a bell, but makes for a better base

title: Flashforge Creator Pro and similar JTech Photonics Laser mount

description.text:
I have removed my left stepper motor and extruder and am replacing it with a 2.8W laser from JTech Photonics. This is the Alpha version (untested) of the mount. It should allow for the laser to shine through the removed extruder hole in the extruder bar. The top plate will need redesigned, i'm still working on that at the moment. I am going to bring this out of Work in Progress Status. The mount, and case are installed and I have finally sorted out the code. Update 4: Part is printed and installed and has been for a few days. Still some minor tweaks but it is working as is. Development will continue. I have also added a case for the laser control board that can be mounted to the rear of the printer. I am working with Simplify3D developers to come up with a profile or method to easily generate a stl that works with the laser. Update 3: Combined both pieces. Have not printed the combined part yet but it should line up fine. I have the laser mounted with the individual pieces and everything lines up great. I'm planning on opening the bot tomorrow and finishing the wiring. Also working on a case to mount the board on the back of the bot. The filament feed tube on the right tool is designed to have a 6mm push lock / 9mm thread insert screw in. Update 2: This is the first print ready version. The laser should be here today and i will get this printed and test fit tonight. Eventually the top piece and laser mount / stepper mount will be one piece. Update 1:
Made some changes to the left stepper replacement when i realized the laser didn't need to be centered. Still a WiP and unprinted. Still working on the top plate.

Follow the instructions on JTechPhotonics website for installation and hookup. Print the controller case and laser mount both with support. You will need to remove: left stepper, fan, heatsink, extruder, heater, thermocouple. Mount laser on mount using 2 m3 nuts (included in spares bag) and some bolts from spares bag. Reuse fan mount bolts and 2 m3 nuts to secure mount to extruder bar. If you have an active cooling fan controlled by M126 / M127 ( the EXTRA header on the AT2650) you will have to disconnect it when using the laser. To print with laser: Install inkscape
Install Inkscape Unicorn to gcode plugin
Generate gcode
Manually edit gcode (See attached examples)

title: FlashForge Creator Dual Extruder Shim for Glass bed add on.

description.text: This is a shim for the FF Creator Dual extruder printer. The purpose of this is if you add a glass plate to your build the printer will need to know to detect the change in depth where the sensor is. The shim triggers the sensor so that the hot ends do not break your glass or scratch it (break it more likely). This one is 3.1mm width, yours may be different. Always make sure to tighten down your bed so it gives you more clearance when you start to level it. Please if you found this part useful - consider donating a dollar or two.

remixed_from.author: AndrewBCN
remixed_from.title: Open Hardware Knurled Knob for M6 Nut

title: Prusa i3 / P3Steel Improved X-axis Printed Parts Collection

description.text:
This collection of parts includes what I consider to be the latest, best designs of printed parts for the X-axis for any Prusa i3 variant, including the P3Steel and the Prusa i3 Twelvepro. Some of them I remixed, some are just as I found them here on Thingiverse or GitHub, and some I created in OpenSCAD. The X-carriage is my earlier thing #586636.
The Open Hardware Knurled Knob used to adjust the tension of the belt is my earlier thing #600955.
The 623ZZ pulley is my earlier thing #602435. I am still researching the proper attribution for some of these parts (see http://reprap.org/wiki/Genealogy_/_Archeology_of_the_Prusa_i3_X_Motor_End), what is certain is that they are all derived from Josef Prusa's original designs which were licensed under the GPLV3, except perhaps for the pulley which I wrote from scratch in OpenSCAD, but that is trivial code; and the knurled knob, derived from other things found here on Thingiverse (with proper attribution). Note that both the X-carriage and the X idler end pulley are for a GT2 belt.

All these parts print easily. I have been printing them in PLA with 40% infill, 0.6mm walls and top/bottom layers.  
The X idler end pulley requires 2 x 623ZZ bearings.  
The reinforced X carriage uses 4 x LM8UU linear bearings instead of the usual 3 bearings.

comments.author: tonyno

comments.text:
Hi Tonyno,
I can guarantee that all these parts slice and print fine, as I have sliced and printed at least three pieces of each. :-) In fact I never publish any design here on Thingiverse before printing it out, usually twice.
Unfortunately some of these parts are not easy to modify for a simple reason: the OpenSCAD source for them is not available. I had to reverse-engineer them in part to be able to make small modifications, and that can be very time-consuming.
Imho if you want to use non-standard linear bearings you would save a lot of time by going back to Josef Prusa's original OpenSCAD designs (available from his GitHub repository), as you will find that the bearing size is just a parameter which you should be able to adjust easily.
Good luck in any case!

title: Heads or Tails - Washington Quarter - Coin Toss Case

description.text:
Keep your lucky quarter handy for those ever important coin tosses.  
Heads or Tails?  
This prints as one piece and could result in damage to your printer; please read the Instructions before printing with a quarter inside!!!!

WARNING CAUTION
Printing of this item with a coin in place may damage your printer. Print at your own risk! I printed this on a Lulzbot TAZ4 with PLA. 0.35 Nozzle
0.2mm Layer height
Inside perimeters first (makes sure print restart is on interior of coin) I have been trying a couple layers of nail polish to help "flatten" the areas around Washington's head. This helps the first "heads" layer to stick to the face of the coin. Pause the print before the "heads" layer to place quarter and restart print. Do not place quarter in print before it has raised to the "head" height layer! I can't stress enough the importance of a calibrated printer and carefully ensuring the quarter is flush before restarting the print. Enjoy!

My Office chair likes to slowly deflate. I created this thing so I could print a few and make my chair stay whatever height I like. I've uploaded two other versions of this thing that should work better. I found the gap in the first version to cause the rings to crush down into each other. I also uploaded v3 with a wider gap as v2 might be too small and fuse together. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/gE8pTrNFW4s

Print as many as you need to keep your office chair at whatever height you like.  You can scale it to fit tighter or looser depending on your chair.  
I recommend you print them with lots of infill.  I printed mine with 3 shells and 25% infill.  The 3 shells made it print nearly solid.  
I ended up having to use zip ties to hold them in place.  If you find that they pop off under pressure you should do the same.

I went to the Cupcake Social 2.0 event in NYC on May 7, and won this awesome pink apron in their raffle.
Being an avid cupcake baker and just loving pink clothing, this was the perfect opportunity for making my long-term vision of being able to bake cupcakes while tweeting my progress in real-time finally becoming a reality. So here I present: The Keyboard Cupcake Apron. The design was inspired by Zach\'s keyboard pants:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:589.
Also thanks to Zach for giving me his leftover keyboard! For more images, see http://www.flickr.com/photos/kintel/sets/72157618070732209/

1) Laser cut the the SVG file out of your material of choice.
2) Sew stitches around the edge of the keyboard. The keyboard is made from silicone and it sews pretty well. To make the middle of the keyboard stick, look for point on the keyboard where the front and back silicone sheets are glued together. These are safe places to make stitches. Another option is stitching through just the top layer, but be careful and use relatively large stitches since the silicone has a tendency of breaking.
3) Enjoy and go bake some cupcakes.

This is some STL files and a parameterized model generation tool using Autodesk Inventor.  It's set up so the dimensions for the nuts and bolts are stored in an Excel spreadsheet, and if you edit the spreadsheet, the model(s) get updated accordingly.

The zip file contains the Inventor part files and the spreadsheet, which all need to be kept in the same folder for the parameter changes to flow. The threads are based on the ISO standards found here (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_metric_screw_thread) with a couple of variations; the tooth pitch isn't restricted to 30 degrees as you can change this in the Excel file, and the tolerance is settable in the spreadsheet as well, so the prints "just work" the first time you print them. Note that the tolerance setting is subtracted from the nut, and the bolt is printed unaltered.

I wiped up a gear generator based on the MCAD 'involute_gears.scad' libarary
Hopefully, this makes creating gears very easy since all you have to do is plug in some numbers and press F6. Options include:
  • recessed sides (single or double sided)
  • gear hub (single or double sided)
  • set screw in the gear hub
  • relief holes
    • UPDATE: V0.76
    Added options for double set screws and setting the distance for the set screw from the end of the hub.
    Renamed everything.
    Added a couple of new examples. Long video of a set of gears baking: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xEBrBUzchbU Another video of gears in action:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xbkGZLXumhg

Example to make a gear with recess sides, double-hubbed with set screw and relief holes (see attached image): EasyBakeGear (circular_pitch = 88, number_of_teeth = 64, gear_thickness = 7, bore_diameter = 3, recess_thickness = 2, recess_diameter = 28, recess_double_side = true, //default false hub_height = 12, hub_diameter=5, double_hub = true, //default false hub_set_screw_diameter=1.9, hub_set_screw_distance = 3, // If 0 or missing, hole is centered hub_set_screw_double_sided = true, num_relief_circles=5, relief_circles_diameter=5 );

comments.text:
Ahhh, I see what happened I think.
Thingiverse replaces the spaces in the filename with underscores. In the message output you get, the very first warning is probably 'WARNING: Can't open include file 'Easy Bake Gear Generator v0.76.scad'.
In the file, you'll see that the first line is 'include ' There are spaces in the filename. But the file you downloaded probably has no spaces. 'Easy_Bake_Gear_Generator_v0.76.scad'
Change the file name to just "Easy Bake Gear Generator v0.76.scad".
comments.author: marcome1701

comments.text: The file called "...Generator.." is just a library file.  You can open the file "32t_spur-8t_pinion_300cp.scad" to create a gear and to use as an example.  Both files must be in the same directory.

description.text:
After 3 versions the edgeslide should be stable both mechanical and version wise.
http://youtu.be/0r5rYepdS4I
I initially had rough travel on one axis and couldn't really pin down the cause. Using dual bearings and moving the belt attchment to be inline with the shaft may have helped but I can't say for certain.
http://nerdipedia.com/tiki-index.php?page=huey

The main part needs to be printer standing on end.
The other part is printed in the same orientation so it mates well.
Both have built in support.
I tried both ABS and PLA and found the ABS distorted. There is an optional nut for screwing down the shaft.
My prints were so tight I haven't needed it. The nut is a M3 flower nut. These come in at least two sizes and I've used a large one - about 5mm across.

Just a quick clip THING allowing you to mount a mirror or a board to a wall. Quite handy, when customized on your needs. Mount your mirror:
  • drill holes for lower clips and fix them carefully (not to much torque)
  • drill holes for upper clips leaving enough space to put mirror
  • fix upper clips not too tight.
  • push clips down after mirror is in place
    • The design is fully parametrized. Use OpenSCAD to reshape the thing @ your needs.
    Adopt screw radius, height, width, deepness, slot length ... Parametrization of the stl files:
    screw hole = 4mm
    thickness = 2.5mm
    height = 25mm
    width = 10 mm
    glas = 5 mm

A simple printed case for the Arduino Nano V3. The bottom half has two rows for the bottom pins. The top design allows access to the reset pin through the center hole and visibility for the four onboard LEDs. The two halves fit together with simple friction and are held together with the help of the natural ridged pattern from fused filament printing.

I've only been able to print with PLA on a Printrbot Simple with the sizes in this model. The bottoms and sides are thin enough that the infill percentage doesn't make much difference. It's a relatively tight fit for the three Nano boards I had available, so I'm not certain if shrinkage with ABS would be an issue.

description.text:
Designed to hold my Hauwei Y550 phone on the wall with all accessibility to the buttons and ports, while being able to be removed easily.
Sticking to the KISS principles (Keep, It, Simple, S...), I was cautions of how long it would take to print while providing a sturdy holder. The phone is held without slop and maybe a firm fit depending on your printers accuracy. the front lips were specifically shaped to not interfere with the buttons or camera while also allowing for USB connection for charging or computer communications. there arches in the back allow for tape adhesion to a wall while minimizing the bridging space for the printer. the front notch enables quick removal of the phone for those urgent calls. The back angles provide stability and a slight lean when mounted on the wall, there are also slots for tape to secure to the wall.

Simply download, slice and print! (some orientation adjustments may be required before slicing)
I attached mine to the wall by running lengths of tape through the back gaps and behind it. alternatively you could leave it as a desktop holder

After minutes and minutes of digging thru the 500 knobs in the bin for the 4 I needed for my new bench power supply, I was reduced to but one knob I could accept, and, to my luck there was only 1. After seconds and seconds of slaving over a medium warm keyboard I was able to engineer a matching knob. 9 prints with 7 failures later, I had two of the valued knob. Proud of my accomplishments I went to test fit it and found out its the wrong style knob for the supply. So here, you take the blooming thing.
Please dont use this knob for evil, unless thats specifically what you need it for.

• First you have to print it.
    2) Insert a bare metal round disc in the front. or a white disc. or a red one... pink dosn't go well with the black so I dont suggest pink
    c) Fit an adapter in the back to go from the 8.5mm to whatever shaft size your putting the knob on. I didn't make any of these that are printable, you can if you like. I have a lathe, I made mine from aluminum.
    Next, If required the knob has provisions for being drilled for a grub screw, drill and insert screw
    Please enjoy this stupid knob.

title: Raspberry Pi (Model B) case with 75mm VESA mount

description.text:
UPDATE (7/12/15): GOOD NEWS! My Raspberry Pi 2 case design is finally finished and ready for download. Go check it out! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:922740 UPDATE (6/8/15): Sorry everyone for dropping the ball on getting the new Raspberry Pi 2 case complete. Development work has started again and I hope to get the new case released soon. Thanks! UPDATE (2/3/15): Just ordered a new Raspberry Pi 2 Model B (same mounting as a B+), so expect a new version of the mount for the newer RPi's soon. UPDATE (12/29/14): Updated STL's of part with correct orientation. Also added STEP files for those who want to modify. None of the other cases shared around the web had to offer exactly what I wanted so I decided to design my own. This was a ground up design, but I have to give credit where credit is due. A lot of design cues and dimensions were borrowed from this case... http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:79036 This Raspberry Pi (Model B) case has a few key features that I wanted...
  • Access slot for Pi camera
  • Screw together design
  • Screw mount raspberry pi to case using standard mounting holes
  • Built in 75mm VESA mounting tabs.
  • Better general fit between components and clearances to all inputs/outputs
  • Rotary engine (reuleaux triangle) vent design
    • Also, the case is designed to use a flush mount microSD card. I use this one and it doesn't stick outside the case at all. http://www.adafruit.com/product/966 If anyone finds any problems (dimensionally or otherwise) post them up so I can get the model fixed.

UPDATE (1/10/15): Some people have said that the fit was a bit tight, so it might be worth scaling up by 0.5% or 1% in your slicer. I haven't tested this though since it worked well as designed for me. I printed these out of ABS with 0.2mm layers and 100% infill since they are pretty thin. Screws for mounting Rasberry Pi to base are #2 size and 1/4" long.
Screws for mounting top to base are #2 size and 1/2" long.

comments.author: palawanisland

comments.text: I'll throw a bit of help out there for folks.   I use the acetone vapor bath to make my ABS parts look nice and smooth.   When using Ultradome, you need to ensure that any parts that have been through that process has completely cured and that all acetone has evaporated from the surface before doming.   Failing to do this will pollute the epoxy causing it to cure poorly, causing the ABS colors to bleed into the epoxy or causing the epoxy not to cure at all!
comments.author: brucethehoon

comments.text: Good to know.
comments.author: brucethehoon

comments.text: What technique did you use to get the epoxy to sit so nicely in the trough which you had printed? I get the feeling that if I tried this, I would end up with strings of the stuff all over the place. Saying that, is 'doming' epoxy something special as I have never heard of it. (If so, does it have a trade name in the UK?)
comments.author: Alzibiff

comments.text: Yes, doming epoxy is special. It has a very high surface tension and it's normally use on top of flat items. Because of the high surface tension it will go to the edge of an item and not run off so filling this clover was very easy as it had walls.

description.text: This is a truncated Icosahedron created by friction welding 20 hexagons together. The individual hexagons are printed separately. After printing the hexagons they are welded together using a Dremel rotary tool and a small section of printer filament. The friction welding process works for PLA, ABS, 1.75mm and 3mm filament. More information on the process used for friction welding this thing is available here: http://www.scorchworks.com/Blog/friction-welding-with-a-dremel-rotary-tool/ EDIT: I updated the SCAD file to make it more easily adjustable from a hexagon to other shapes and added comments.

title: Pan and Tilt for Durafly P51D

description.text:
This Pan and Tilt will fit into the cockpit of the Durafly P51D.
You will need:
Two 9g servos
One Cross arm
One single arm
Four servo mounting screws
spy cam

this is a simple build and print in PLA the camera is a spy camera from EBAY
To Assemble:
Glue the cross servo arm to the Lower Mount so you can still screw the servo arm to the servo to mount:
-First work out where in the cockpit floor you wish to put the Pan servo.
-secure the Lower Mount to the Pan servo with the required screw.
-insert the camera mount into the Upper Mount and secure with bolt and nut ( I used ones from a Helicopter blade holder )
-connect the tilt servo arm to the camera mount with a push rod (again from a 450 helicopter rotor head)
-center the tilt servo then attach the servo arm.
  • fit the tilt servo into the Lower mount, then secure the Upper Mount with the servo mounting screws.
  • test movement does not bind by using a servo tester or connect to your RC equipment
  • insert the spy camera and wire to you VTx
    • link to youtube of it mounted in the mustang
    http://youtu.be/tsLCf2J7AWg

title: Parametric Printable Threaded Rod / Leadscrew and Nut

description.text:
A parametric version of PacManFan's excellent threaded rod / leadscrew!  
Can be a little stiff at first, but becomes smooth-running with a little bit of work and/or filing/sanding down.  
Print it, try it, use it to make something cool!
Just download and print. No need for support material.

comments.text: What is the sturdiest way of printing this (Horiz flat / vert tall) so it holds up to being screwed and unscrewed regularly?
comments.author: Pouljin

comments.text:
I recommend printing this vertical. If printed horizontal, I think the sag and distortion would be too much for it to run smoothly (and it might be hard to get it to stick to the print bed).
Printing it vertically does mean it won't have as high tensile strength or be as flexible, but you can always scale it up!

I took the mechanical endstop and remixed it: Through-hole components (which I have on-hand)
New style connector
Single-sided with no airwires Hasn't been printed yet. I plan to print 4 and add auto-homing to the x and y axes. UPDATE 2/5: It's getting closer to printing now. I sized the board properly, took away some extraneous text. A lot of the obvious clearance issues were cleaned up. When I print it on paper (which, I know, wicks the ink much more than copper), it still looks like it's too tight and there's a lot of bleed between traces. UPDATE 2/7: I fixed most of the issues and whatnot I was seeing before - got rid of most of the ground plane by setting isolation to 100 mils... made the labels larger and easier to read... I'm still not sure the vias will print out properly, other than that I think this one is ready to go.

Print with 0.5mm ultra-fine tip sharpie on single or double-sided PCB. Let dry and re-print several times. Decide if you want to surface-mount your components; this is done by bending the leads out to match the traces and clipping them before soldering. If double-sided and you're surface-mounting use tape or sharpie to completely mark the underside of the board. This will speed up etching and reduce acid usage. Etch. Solder components. According to this page: http://wiki.makerbot.com/cupcake-cnc-10:cupcake-endstop-installation the correct wiring (with my labeling in parentheses) is:
Blue - 5V (aka +5)
Green - signal (aka OUT)
Brown - Ground (aka GND)

author: MichaelAtOz

description.text:
This is a filament drive for a bowden type extruder.
Based on the very successful Air tripper design. I wanted to make a few changes to increase the strength of that design and have ports for 1/8" BSPT fittings. It is also suitable for 3mm filament.

BOM:
5ea M3x25 screws, pan head or socket head will work.
1ea M3 Nut
2ea M4x60 screws
2ea M4 Nut
M8x20 grub screw or anything 8mm diameter and 20mm long
608ZZ bearing
625ZZ bearing
8mm hobbed drive pulley
NEMA17 stepper motor
2ea springs for tensioning about 25x6mm 0.8mm wire dia.
2ea M4 washers
M4 bolts for mounting extruder
4mm pneumatic quick connect fitting 1/8" BSPT of NPT if using 1.75mm filament. The drive can be used for feeding in either direction. Just choose which side to fit the pneumatic fitting to. After printing there is a section of support material to be removed from the body.
Drill the filament tube out to 3.5 or 4mm if you are using 3mm filament. As long as you use 3 or 4 perimeter passes.

It's a flat-fold flippin' phone stand! This folding phone stand has 5 angle settings: 30°, 45°, 50°, 55° and 60°. The best thing about it? It can be folded into a 8mm-thick piece of flat plastic! Suitable for most smartphones not thicker than 12mm. 2D dimensions: 50mm x 60mm (alt. size provided: 50mm x 80mm)
Thickness of each part: 4mm
Holder hook depth: 10.5mm ~ 12.2mm
Holder notches gap: 24mm No bolts required, just print and assemble. Refer to the instructions.
This thing is created with FreeCAD. Source files included.

Parts:
  • 1x Backplate
  • 1x Base
  • 2x Hook
  • 1x Stand
    • Note that for the backplate and hook models, there is a variant with support and it is recommended to use that variant. For the base and the stand, the given size is 50x60mm, but an alternative size of 50x80mm is available. You can also download the freecad source files and adjust the dimensions yourself (though be extremely careful since changing the constraints will sometimes mess up other parts. Print Instructions:
  • Print with no support.
    • The backplate and hook models already contains custom brim and support for easier printing, but you can choose to print the models without them. Do note that even though cleaning up the support is kind of a PITA, printing without may be even more troublesome.
    • The recommended layer height is 0.1mm with 0.2mm first layer.
    • If you use an extra brim, make sure to clean up the brim around the hinge axles.
  • Cut away the brim and support, and sand if necessary.
  • Assemble the stand. Do note that there is a flat position on the hinges which allows easier insertion at a certain angle. Use your hand to feel the hinge to decide the insertion angle. Refer to the instruction image.
  • Flip and place phone on it. :)

description.text:

I'd almost advise against printing it, because it requires a HUGE amount of support material - more than 2/3 of the material you'll use is waste! I didn't want to print it upside down, as my experience is that Lego bricks don't fit well when you have to hack away the support. Tolerances are surprisingly small. But please feel free to remix!

title: Nasa Space Wrench (actual file from Nasa)

description.text:
Hot off the press .... 23rd December...just in time for Christmas.
This is the first ever tool emailed to space and printed in orbit!
I haven't even had time to print it yet, it's that hot. I found it here:
http://nasa3d.arc.nasa.gov/detail/wrench-mis ...but the file wouldn't download on either IE8 or Firefox.
It did download on Android, but wouldn't agree to being transmitted to a PC. Finally I made it work by zipping in Android and transmitting the .zip to the PC. I guess the engineers in Nasa, despite their brains the size of planets, forgot to change the file permissions? Anyway, here it is for all Earth-dwellers to enjoy! UPDATE:
I did a print in PLA on my K8200. 0.2mm layers.
I think the centre section is meant to turn and ratchet. But mine fused together :o(
Think the clearance needs to be increased for mere earth-bound printers.
YMMV....

comments.text: One article (https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/research/news/3Dratchet_wrench) mentioned 104 layers, which translates to a 0.25mm layer height. I'd avoid PLA due to its rigidity; the pawl contains a spring which needs to be somewhat flexible. I'm assuming that ABS is the proper material.

I successfully printed, 1st try, in PLA.
200° temp, 0 bed, .4 nozzle, .1 layer, 1.2 shell & bottom/top layer, 25% infill, 70mm/sec, no raft.

comments.text:
ABS layer adhesion is as strong or stronger as PLA if print temperature is correct. Many hot ends do not have the correct temperature calibration and ABS ends up printing with a temperature that is too cold. I have have an E3D V6 lite and always crank up to the max. 245C for better adhesion results. I have just got an E3D V6 All-metal clone and will be experimenting with 250 and up for large ABS prints without cracking to attempt this:
http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?262,434083

Put a motor on your TinyWing!! This mount is designed for the Tinywing, a small (~2'/60cm) foamboard flying wing designed by Cacomistle and posted on FliteTest.com: http://www.flitetest.com/articles/tinywing He didn't post the file for his printed motor mount, so I made one myself. With my background in submarines, I overengineer everything,so it's reasonably robust for a tiny motor mount. The motor I made it for is from Hobby King, the C2222 Micro brushless Outrunner 2850kv, it's a little bitty thing, but plenty to fly the TinyWing!
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=43360

Printed in ABS at 0.2mm layer thickness, 5mm brim, no support.  I recommend printing several at once because it avoids having the hotend on one area too much in small prints like this.  It also gives you more motor mounts to make more small planes! :)  
After printing and any cleanup necessary, the motor mount gets hot-glued to the underside of the back of the wing as seen in the pics above.

author: fenquick

description.text:
With this thing, you can make shot glasses made of ice. It is made in OpenSCAD and it's fully parametric. Changes in version 1.1:
  • added a centralWedgeSpace parameter, default to 1 mm, as per Linkreincarnate's feedback (pot_1.0.stl is not changed, you can print it)
  • slightly changed the algorithm that positions the caps near the pot, eg when rendering both together
    • Changes in version 1.2:
  • fixed a bug: the chosen glass thickness was right only at the top border of the glass (pot_1.0.stl is not changed, you can print it)

The provided source is well documented, feel free to modify it.
Almost everything can be customized by passing the right parameters, like for example icy glass height, width, thickness and so on. For example, the published stl was generated with this call in OpenSCAD:
IceShotGlassMaker(45, 40, 50);
In this example, the printed parts will allow to make an icy glass tall 45 mm, with the base 40 mm wide and the top 50 mm wide. There are many other other parameters that can be changed, see the source code for more info. How to make an icy glass:
  • Print the two parts
  • Fill the pot with water
  • Push the cap in it, letting excess water flow
  • Let it rest in the freezer until it freezes.
  • Remove the cap and extract the icy glass
  • Don't drink too much :)

comments.text: if the water go out, you can try mix water with agar agar (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agar) before freeze
comments.author: 3Dmatic

comments.text: I too have been having this issue. did you find any solution?
comments.author: sscherrer

comments.text: Anyone got a fix for leaky glasses? I printed one, but it leaks like hell! All the precious water just flows out!  :(
comments.author: deeeep

comments.text: Temporary fix is to freeze the glasses upside down, the wedge apparently leaks less than the bottom of the glass.... fingers crossed. Water is freezing!
comments.author: deeeep

comments.text: I had a little trouble with the cap, shown in my picture of it. Forgot to check the preview before printing. I'm using ReplicatorG 0025 and Skeinforge 35. The internal wedge was treated as hollow, and one surface didn't print. I commented out sections of the .scad file, and discovered that removing the top wedge makes the internal wedge behave correctly. Not sure why this would be the case. Something strange in Skeinforge, perhaps. I'm trying some simple changes to see if I can get it to behave correctly.
comments.author: bld

comments.text: I added 1 to the height of the internal wedge (and the glass height to make up for it). This put it above the top wedge enough to print 3 solid layers. Bridged, but they came out. Printed successfully.
comments.author: bld

comments.text: Your Sizes are a bit off/  The center part in the top needs t be smaller. I has t take out the outside shells to make it fit I would make the center part f the top like a millimeter less in radius...
